fields.summary: Console changes instance protocol to HTTPS when requested one was HTTP

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: I have a listener with https as instance protocol and the backend authentication policy. I also have another listener with http as instance protocol (therefore no backend auth policy). The listener table shows that both have the backend auth policy.
fields.summary: ELB listener table shows incorrect backend auth policy info

comments.body: looks from the table screenshot like both have https, one has port 80 though instead of 443.
[~spark], thank you so much for finding and filing all these bugs! It's really helping get the feature hardened on the front and back ends. You rock!
[~spark]: Did you configure a back-end policy for the listener with HTTPS/443 on the ELB side and HTTP/80 on the instance side?
[~kgill] I did it for HTTPS-443, HTTPS-443. That one was created before the faulty one and then the new one seems to copy it from the previous one.
assigned to [~ccassler] for investigation. May move into 4.2.1 depending on what he finds out.

I think we need to fix GUI-2175 before we can prove this bug.  I'm seeing behavior related to the other bug where I attempted to create a listener with client side HTTP 8888 and instance side HTTPS 443.  I also assigned a certificate to the listener.  After I completed and saved the ELB, the instance side changed to HTTP 443 and the certificate was not saved.  This seems to be related to GUI-2175.
[~ccassler], the blocking ticket was merged, so can you take a look again?  (into maint-4.2)

[~spark]: I think I created the listeners identical to what you were referring to in this bug.  However, now, I can only assign the back-end certificate when the listener has instance-side SSL protocol enabled.  If the client-side has HTTPS/SSL enabled, I can only assign the client side SSL certificate NOT the back-end certificate.  This seems correct to me.  Let me know your thoughts.

[~ccassler] back-end certificate is about only instance-side protocol. The issue was that the listener table shows that the listener with non-SSL/HTTPS instance-side protocol had the backend certificate (which is not possible). Probably the table was displaying the info incorrectly.
[~spark]: Yeah, I think that was happening because of GUI-2175 which is fixed.  I will resolve this issue then.
